abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Customs Modernization
            Project (CMP) for Vietnam were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was high; Bank
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory; borrower
            performance was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: project ownership. The beneficiary is a
            fundamental requirement for successful outcomes. The General
            Department of Vietnam Customs (GDVC) has not abandoned its
            objectives but chosen to adopt a different financing path to
            meet their Information and Communications Technology (ICT)
            needs other than through the VCMP. Project implementation
            design quality. A realistic, detailed implementation plan is
            an essential underpinning of any investment project. The CMP
            was prepared relatively quickly with the assistance of a
            Policy and Human Resource Development Fund (PHRD) grant, but
            project implementation arrangements were not fully adequate
            and implementation schedule was overoptimistic without clear
            sequencing and no provision for delay. Project management
            unit format and capacity. The CMP Project Management Unit
            (PMU) proved unable to manage the planned institutional
            development program in such a way as to meet the
            implementation schedule. Due to delays it was not fully
            tested in managing an infrastructure investment program. The
            enclave format has merit in regard to investment project
            management not least in simplifying the fiduciary duties of
            the parties but is less effective in fostering institutional
            development which typically benefits from an integrated
            format in which the unit is embedded in the
            institution's own functional structure. Supervision and
            monitoring. Project progress was monitored by sector
            management and the country portfolio management team through
            the Implementation Supervision Report (ISR) system reports,
            and by Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) and
            Ministry of Finance (MoF) through the Aligned Monitoring
            Tool (AMT) reports which were also available to the Bank
            task team and portfolio management team. The aides-memoir of
            the early missions identified emerging implementation issues
            and although helpful suggestions were made the measures
            proposed were not always fully successful. ISR reports
            lacked some detail and did not sufficiently highlight the
            consequences of increasingly serious delays and project
            management weaknesses.
